The pilot scheme has also been introduced in the Tallaght-Clondalkin area where a group of schools with similar difficulties has been identified. A total of 27 counsellor teacher posts have been allocated under this initiative and seven of these posts have been allocated to the north inner city schools.

Qst.askee: Minister for Education
Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, she has to find a place for a person (details supplied) in Dublin 6W for the school year commencing 1 September 1995; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Ms Bhreathnach) Niamh Bhreathnach
Speaker.P: I am aware of the case referred to by the Deputy. The selection and enrolment of pupils in secondary schools is, in the first instance, the responsibility of individual schools. These efforts, which by their nature can take some time, are ongoing in this case and every effort is being made to find an appropriate placement. I shall advise the Deputy of any developments.

Qst.hpid: Mr. S. Brennan Mr. S. Brennan
Qst.askee: Minister for Justice
Qst.Quest: if she will sanction the return of a deactivated revolver belonging to a person (details supplied) in Dublin 24 in view of the fact that this item is considered a family heirloom and was surrendered under the Firearms (Temporary Custody) Order, 1972; whether the ongoing peace process now allows this item to be returned under a provision of the Firearms and Offensive Weapons Act, 1990; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice (Mrs. Owen) Nora Owen
Speaker.P: The Deputy is aware from correspondence with my predecessor that under existing Government policy the Garda authorities are not authorised to issue firearms certificates to persons wishing to hold pistols or revolvers. There is a provision in the Firearms and Offensive Weapons Act, 1990, which allows a superintendent of the Garda Síochána to issue, in certain circumstances, an authorisation to a person wishing to hold a deactivated firearm. However, legal advice available to my Department is to the effect that at the time when an authorisation is sought the firearm in question must be defective.

I have brought the case referred to by the Deputy to the attention of the Garda authorities and requested a report indicating whether or not they consider that the weapon is deactivated, and I will communicate with the Deputy when I have this information to hand.

Qst.askee: Minister for Social Welfare
Qst.Quest: the cost of giving a 5 per cent increase in social welfare and assistance payments to permanent residents on offshore islands.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa) Proinsias De Rossa
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Proinsias De Rossa)
Speaker.P: The population of inhabitants of offshore islands is around 9,600 — 1991 Census, Central Statistics Office. The number of those in receipt of a social welfare payment is not separately available. The cost of an increase specifically targeted at offshore island residents cannot, therefore, be estimated. However, it is estimated that the full year cost of a 1 per cent general increase in social welfare weekly rates is approximately £41,000 for every 1,000 recipients.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. Yates) Ivan Yates

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Mushroom Industry.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry
Qst.Quest: his views on the state of the mushroom industry (details supplied) in the Border counties; and if his Department will consult with the Department of Finance in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. Yates) Ivan Yates
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. Yates)
Speaker.P: The mushroom industry has grown substantially in recent years from output valued at £36 million in 1989 to £54 million in 1993. It provides valuable employment in rural areas. Exports continue to grow.
I recognise that the strength of our currency relative to sterling has — at least in the short term — created a more difficult environment in the UK which is our main export outlet.

The industry has made representations on a number of occasions regarding the interpretation of the legislation relating to the taxation of casual workers. This has been fully examined by the relevant Departments which are satisfied that the provisions are being correctly applied to the mushroom sector.

MainHeading.P: Despite the difficulties being encountered by the industry I believe that it still represents an attractive investment opportunity. I believe the industry will continue to improve and remain competitive.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Appointment of Representative Organisations.

Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: if he will consider appointing a person with a disability as a representative of organisations such as the Disability Federation of Ireland to the Interdepartmental Committee on Transport Accessibility, and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry) Michael Lowry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry)
Speaker.P: The committee to which the Deputy refers is essentially a small working group chaired by my Department and comprised of representatives from a number of public sector organisations — the Departments of Health and Equality and Law Reform, Bus Átha Cliath, Bus Éireann, Iarnród Éireann and the National Rehabilitation Board. Consequently, the committee is already in a position to bring a broad range of relevant skills and perspectives, including a keen awareness of user needs, to bear on the task of securing such improvements in accessibility to all modes of public transport as can be implemented within the resources available to public transport providers and other relevant bodies.

I believe that the present composition of the committee is the most appropriate arrangement in the context of that remit and I have no plans to broaden the scope of the representation. Of course, it is open to bodies such as the Disability Federation of Ireland to make their views known to the committee on issues falling within its area of concern.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Proposed Second Airport in Dublin.

Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: the Government's policy in relation to the proposal to build a second airport in Dublin.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry) Michael Lowry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry)
Speaker.P: The need for a second airport at Dublin would fall to be examined by the Government in the context of existing and projected traffic volumes and capacity requirements.
I should add that, in conjunction with Aer Rianta, who manage the State airports on my behalf, capacity requirements at the three State airports are kept under continual review by my Department.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - Power Supply Fee.

Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: the reason Government Departments are required to pay a fee to a private company (details supplied) in order to get a power supply from a semi-State body; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry) Michael Lowry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry)
Speaker.P: As Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications, I do not have a statutory function in relation to the safety and technical standards for electrical contracting work. The Electro-Technical Council of Ireland specifies standards for electrical installation work. I am concerned, however, that the public should be able to rely on an acceptable standard of workmanship, and have therefore welcomed efforts by the industry to ensure that adequate technical standards are applied.

MainHeading.P: The company to which the Deputy refers was set up as a non-statutory, self-regulatory body for the electrical contracting industry. The objective of the body is to oversee the application of satisfactory standards for electrical installation work. In support of the registration process the Electricity Supply Board stipulated that, with effect from 1 September 1992, electrical supplies would only be connected to installations where (a) a member of the body in question certified that work complied with the national wiring rules or (b) where an inspector employed by that body certified that work by a non member complied with the wiring rules. Each inspection is subject to a fee.

Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: the normal transport cost for general hauliers operating in Ireland; the comparative figures for our EU counterparts; the measures, if any, he intends to introduce to rectify the situation; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry) Michael Lowry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry)
Speaker.P: My Department does not have the comparative data of the kind mentioned by the Deputy. Transport costs which affect general hauliers in this country include such items as excise duties, fuel taxes, insurance, port charges and labour costs all of which are outside the scope of my remit at the Department of Transport, Energy and Communications.

It is generally accepted that Irish hauliers are disadvantaged by comparison with their European competitors due to our island/peripheral location. As part of the national development plan very significant investment in this country's transport system is being made which will improve internal and access transport infrastructure and facilities on an integrated basis, thereby reducing transport costs. The reliability of the transport system will also be improved by removing bottlenecks, remedying capacity deficiencies and reducing absolute journey times.

Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: his views on whether the Radiological Protection Institute of Ireland has adequate resources to carry out all its functions; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry) Michael Lowry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry)
Speaker.P: The Radiological Protection Institute of Ireland is financed by grant-in-aid from the Exchequer and by income from the provision of radiological protection services and from research contracts. The grant-in-aid to the Institute in 1995 amounts to £1.1 million which includes a capital allocation of £150,000. The institute was also grant-aided an amount of £115,000 towards the radiological emergency plan. The amount grant-aided to the institute this year is identical to the level of funding requested by them.
The level of funding required by the institute to carry out its functions is examined each year in the context of the Department's expenses.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers. - European Single Aviation Market.

Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: the current position regarding the European Single Aviation Market; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry) Michael Lowry
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mr. Lowry)
Speaker.P: The Single Market in air transport came into effect from 1 January 1993 and Irish national law has been amended, where necessary, to take full account of the Single Market conditions. The Single Market for air transport purposes now comprises the 15 member states and also Norway and Iceland. The rules which came into effect on 1 January 1993 cover the areas of air carrier licensing, access for Community air carriers to intra-Community air routes, fares and rates for air services, and amendments to Regulations laying down the procedure for the application of the rules on competition to undertakings in the air transport sector and on the application of Article 85 (3) of the Treaty to certain categories of agreements and concerted practices in the air transport sector.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Defence (Mr. Barrett) Minister for Defence (Mr. Barrett)
Speaker.P: I wish to refer the Deputy to the reply given by my predecessor on 6 April 1995 which was as follows:

Those flights were either for military purposes, including training, or in response to requests from various Government Departments. Qst.askee: Minister for the Marine
Qst.Quest: if he will make an Order under section 39 of the Fisheries Act, 1980, regarding access to a point known as Ballantines Pier, Lough Arrow, County Sligo, where locals are being prevented access to the public pier erected by Sligo County Council.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Mr. Barrett) Minister for the Marine (Mr. Barrett)
Speaker.P: Section 39 of the Fisheries Act, 1980, provides that the Central or a Regional Fisheries Board may apply to the Minister for an Order to be made creating a right of way by a particular route over any land to enable a board to perform statutory functions under the Act or to enable fishermen to gain access to fishing waters. No application for such an Order in relation to access to Ballantines Pier has been made to date.

I understand that anglers have experienced difficulty in gaining access to Ballantines Pier on Lough Arrow. The North Western Regional Fisheries Board is aware of these difficulties and is currently in discussion with Sligo County Council and Bord Fáilte with a view firstly to clarifying whether a public right of way to the pier already exists.
